steps.title: overview
steps.content:
Several African countries rank among the top exporters of arabica coffee worldwide. Ethiopia is the ninth largest exporter followed by Uganda (#15), Kenya (#18) and Tanzania (#19). Concerns over the impacts of increasing minimum (or nighttime) temperatures resulting in decreased yields and increased damage from pest already threatens global coffee production.

Elevations ranging between 1,200 to 1,800 meters (from mean sea level) will feel the most considerable impact in East Africa. The suitable areas for coffee production will transition to higher elevations as temperatures increase, shifting deforestation to new areas.

Vulnerability

Coffee production and access to electricity

East Africa

Coffee growing areas in northern Uganda and northwestern Tanzania have little access to gridded electricity.

Deforestation, linked to fuelwood usage in these areas, could increase with clearing of land for crops like coffee.

steps.aside:
Vulnerability

Coffee production and women's literacy

East Africa

Improved cultivation techniques such as agroforestry show promise for increasing the resilience of coffee production to climate change. The high rates of illiteracy, particularly among women, in northern Uganda and throughout Ethiopia must be taken into account by agricultural extension programs.

steps.title: insights
steps.subtitle: African coffee production
steps.content:
Studies show that climate change may reduce the suitable areas for coffee production by over half by 2050 and up to 65% in East Africa by 2080 (CITATION). Within the Tanzania highlands, increases in daily minimum temperatures have direct correlation with decreased yields.

Agroforestry techniques have proven successful in other parts of the world for increasing the resilience of coffee production to temperature change. In order to be impactful in rural areas of Africa, these programs must take into account barriers in accessing information due to high rates of illiteracy and low access to education. Interventions like fair trade and crop diversification may prove most beneficial by providing alternative income streams, improved nutrition and reduced pests for small holder farmers.
